articles.description:
WASHINGTON DC, Nov 02 (IPS) - Report after report highlights that we can only achieve the greenhouse gas (GHG) emission reductions required by the climate goals of the Paris Agreement if much of the existing coal power generation capacity is retired early.  To this end, one concept that deserves greater consideration is conducting an auction for early retirement of coal power plants worldwide: a global coal retirement auction. This article sets out the broad outlines of how this global auction might operate.

Read the full story, “Early Coal Retirement: How about a Global Auction”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Early Coal Retirement: How about a Global Auction

articles.description:
DUBLIN, Ireland, Nov 02 (IPS) - Before she was murdered in Honduras in 2016, the Lenca Indigenous woman and human rights defender Berta Cáceres poignantly said: “They are afraid of us because we are not afraid of them.”

Read the full story, “A Beacon of Light in Dark Times: the Dublin Platform for Human Rights Defenders”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: A Beacon of Light in Dark Times: the Dublin Platform for Human Rights Defenders

articles.description:
URBANA, Illinois, USA, Nov 02 (IPS) - The statistics are stark. The crisis is unprecedented. Yet again, according to the United Nations, famine looms in Somalia, with hundreds of thousands already facing starvation. In addition, droughts, and catastrophic hunger levels have left over 500,000 children malnourished and at risk of dying. This is already nearly 200,000 more than the 2011 famine. Urgent immediate actions must be taken now, both to address the crisis in the short-term and long-term.

Read the full story, “Tackling Recurring Hunger Crises at the Horn of Africa - Beginning with Somalia”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Tackling Recurring  Hunger Crises at the Horn of Africa - Beginning with Somalia

articles.description:
MEXICO CITY, Nov 02 (IPS) - A beige line slashes its way through the Mayan jungle near the municipality of Izamal in the southeastern Mexican state of Yucatán. It is section 3, 172 kilometers long, of the Mayan Train (TM), the most important megaproject of President Andrés Manuel López Obrador's administration.

Read the full story, “Mexican Environmental Prosecutor's Office Dodges Charges against Mayan Train”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Mexican Environmental Prosecutor's Office Dodges Charges against Mayan Train

Growing tensions over Taiwan. Huge population displacements. Energy crisis. Economic turmoil. Rising global hunger and inequality.

articles.description:
SYDNEY and DAKAR, Nov 01 (IPS) - Developing countries have long been told to avoid borrowing from central banks (CBs) to finance government spending. Many have even legislated against CB financing of fiscal expenditure.

Central bank fiscal financing Such laws are supposedly needed to curb inflation – below 5%, if not 2% – to accelerate growth. These arrangements have also constrained a potential CB developmental role and government ability to respond better to crises.

Read the full story, “Developing Countries Need Monetary Financing”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Developing Countries Need Monetary Financing

articles.description: The summer of 1994 was uncharacteristically warm for Great Britain. Hot, sunny days were followed by close, sticky nights — and by the end of June, pressure had started to build. The last week of the month was an explosive one, meteorologically and culturally. On Friday June 24, an exceptionally severe thunderstorm hit the south east of the UK, diffusing so much grass pollen it triggered a sudden and short-lived asthma epidemic. Two days later, and after years of mounting speculation, the British press broke the news that Prince Charles had accidentally revealed his unfaithfulness to Princess Diana during an ITN documentary. (When asked if he had stayed loyal to his wife, the Prince of Wales nodded. "Yes absolutely," he said before adding of his marriage "until it became irretrievably broken down.")
articles.title: Remember the story behind Princess Diana's revenge dress?

articles.description: In the US border town of Niagara Falls, residents accustomed to the soothing roar of the famous waterfalls recently discovered a much less pleasant sound: the "haunting hum" of bitcoin mining farms. Bitcoin mining farms have multiplied in the United States since China halted this activity in 2021. The United States is now emerging as a global leader in the industry.

articles.description: Shehbaz Sharif arrived in Beijing on Tuesday night on a two-day visit. This is his first visit to China since assuming office in April this year. However, this is Shebaz's second meeting with Xi after becoming the prime minister. He met Xi last month on the sidelines of the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation (SCO) summit at Samarkand in Uzbekistan.
articles.title: Pak PM meets Chinese prez; both agree to strengthen all-weather ties

articles.description: A blast hit a bus carrying Taliban administration employees in the Afghan capital on Wednesday morning, police said, injuring seven people. "Due to a blast on a mini bus from the ministry of rural rehabilitation and development, seven have been injured," said Khalid Zadran, Kabul's police spokesperson, adding the explosion was caused by a roadside mine.
articles.title: Blast in Kabul hits bus carrying Taliban admin employees, injures seven

articles.description: The world must respond firmly to any Russian attempts to disrupt Ukraine's grain export corridor, President Volodymyr Zelenskiy said, as more ships were loading despite Moscow suspending its participation in a U.N.-brokered deal. One of the global consequences of Russia's war on its neighbour has been food shortages and a cost of living crisis in many countries, and a deal brokered by the United Nations and Turkey on July 22 had provided safe passage for vessels carrying grain and other fertiliser exports.
articles.title: Zelenskyy demands firmer defence of Ukraine grains export corridor

articles.description: With Russian artillery exploding around him, a Ukrainian soldier takes shelter in a tunnel and recounts the scene at the front line in Bakhmut, just a kilometre away. "It's horror over there. The ground is black like asphalt. Everything is destroyed," 38-year-old serviceman Yevgen told AFP. "There are bodies everywhere".

articles.description: Authorities in the Ukrainian capital Kyiv are preparing more than 1,000 heating points throughout the city in case its district heating system is disabled by continued Russian attacks, mayor Vitali Klitschko said on Wednesday. articles.description:
Former Israeli Prime Minister and Likud party leader Benjamin Netanyahu speaks to supporters through inside a modified truck with a side bulletproof glass during a campaign event on October 29, 2022 in Bnei Brak. | Amir Levy/Getty Images
    

  
The radical rightward shift of the Israeli body politic, explained by an expert.
 As votes are being tabulated in Israel’s fifth election since 2019, Benjamin Netanyahu’s coalition has taken the lead, meaning he is likely the country’s next leader. He’s been prime minister several times before, but there’s something different this time — and it’s not only that he’s under investigation for serious corruption charges.
Bibi Netanyahu is poised to lead a coalition that is more ideologically unified and further to the extreme right than previous coalit…
articles.title: Netanyahu and the far right have triumphed. Here’s what it means for Israel.

articles.description:
Israeli soldiers stop a vehicle at a checkpoint south of the city of Nablus in the occupied West Bank on November 1, as Palestinian protesters demand the reopening of roads around the closed-off city, which has been under military lockdown since October 11. | Jaafar Ashtiyeh/AFP via Getty Images
    

  
The Lions’ Den, a new Palestinian resistance group, has emerged. Here’s what that says about the state of the Israel-Palestine conflict. 
 As Israel headed to the polls for its fifth election since 2019, Israeli forces have spent the last month putting Palestinian cities in the occupied West Bank under siege. 
Since early October, the city of Nablus has been choked off by Israeli settlers. Nablus and the refugee camp of Jenin, both in the West Bank, have also been the site of Israeli secur…
articles.title: Israel votes. Palestine is under siege.

articles.description:
President of Brazil Jair Bolsonaro looks on during a press conference two days after being defeated by Lula da Silva in the presidential runoff at Alvorada Palace on November 1, 2022, in Brasilia, Brazil. | Andressa Anholete/Getty Images
    

  
Still, his administration confirmed that the presidential transition is beginning, as Lula prepares to take over on January 1.
 Brazilian president Jaír Bolsonaro finally spoke to the country on Tuesday — almost 48 hours after losing the presidential runoff election to political rival and former president Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva.
Bolsonaro, in a very short speech, did not concede the election or recognize Lula’s victory. Instead, he said he would follow the Constitution. He thanked his voters and addressed protests and pro-Bolsonaro trucker road…
articles.title: Bolsonaro finally speaks — but doesn’t concede the election

articles.description:
House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-CA) speaks at a vigil at the Martin Luther King Jr. Memorial on April 4, 2022, in Washington, DC.  | Sarah Silbiger/Getty Images
    

  
For years, Republicans made Nancy Pelosi out to be a public enemy. The attack on her home is the result.
 Friday’s brutal attack on House Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s husband, Paul Pelosi, at their San Francisco home was overtly political — and a logical endpoint to the decades of deeply personal villainization Speaker Pelosi has weathered from her political opponents.
It’s now clear the speaker was the target of Friday’s attack. The assailant broke into the home looking for her, reportedly shouting, “Where is Nancy?” — echoing what insurrectionists called out when they breached the US Capitol on January 6, 2021 — and saying that …
articles.title: The Pelosi attack is the culmination of longtime GOP hate-mongering

articles.description:
Candidate Luiz Inácio Lula Da Silva waves to supporters next to his wife, Rosangela Janja da Silva, after being elected president of Brazil over incumbent Bolsonaro by a thin margin on the runoff at Paulista Avenue on October 30 in São Paulo, Brazil. | Mauro Horita/Getty Images
    

  
Brazil’s political elite — including Bolsonaro’s allies — have acknowledged Lula’s win defeating the incumbent. 
 Former President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva defeated the incumbent Jaír Bolsonaro in Sunday’s runoff elections in Brazil. Lula’s victory returns the leftist leader to power, as the country’s electorate rejected four years of Bolsonaro’s right-wing rule — a result that many of Brazil’s leaders, including those on the right, have acknowledged, except Bolsonaro himself.
Bolsonaro has yet to concede …
articles.title: Lula wins, Bolsonaro shuts up

articles.title: Left-wing Lula wins Brazilian presidential election

articles.description: Alexander Lukashenko has remained a close ally of President Putin but has struggled to muster support for the invasion of Ukraine among his own army.
articles.title: Russian military desperate for supplies as Belarus forced to ‘plug gaps’ in Moscow’s army

articles.description: The head of Ukraine's military intelligence has bizarrely claimed Vladimir Putin has at least three body doubles as rumours abound of the Russian president's declining health.
articles.title: Putin accused of having three 'body doubles' amid bizarre claim he's dead

articles.description: Virgin billionaire Sir Richard Branson has turned down an invitation from the Singapore government to debate the death penalty live on TV.
articles.title: Virgin boss Sir Richard Branson turns down TV debate on death penalty

sources.title: France 24 - International breaking news, top stories and headlines

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Nuno Mendes scored the winning goal within moments of coming on as a second-half substitute as Paris Saint-Germain beat Juventus 2-1 in Turin on Wednesday but the French side missed out on top spot in Champions League Group H in dramatic fashion to a rampant Benfica.
articles.title: PSG beat Juventus but lose top spot in Champions League group to Benfica

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Warning that democracy itself is in peril, President Joe Biden called on Americans Wednesday night to use their ballots in next week's midterm elections to stand up against lies, violence and dangerous “ultra MAGA" election disruptors who are trying to “succeed where they failed” in subverting the 2020 elections.
articles.title: 'Democracy is at risk': Biden warns about political violence ahead of midterms

articles.author: FRANCE24
articles.description: Residents of Niagara Falls, USA, are used to the roar of the famous waterfalls that give the town its name. But for some, a new and far more unpleasant noise has taken its place: The constant hum of Bitcoin mining farms that have sprung up nearby in recent years.
articles.title: 'Constant noise': Bitcoin mining brings misery for Niagara Falls residents

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Parkland school shooter Nikolas Cruz formally received a sentence of life without parole Wednesday after families of his 17 slain victims spent two days berating him as evil, a coward, a monster and a subhuman.
articles.title: Parkland shooter sentenced to life in prison for school massacre

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: The two largest US pharmacy chains, CVS Health and Walgreen Co., announced agreements in principle on Wednesday to pay about $5 billion each to settle lawsuits nationwide over the toll of opioids, and a lawyer said Walmart, a third pharmacy behemoth, is in discussions for a deal.
articles.title: US pharmacies announce opioid settlements totaling $10 billion

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: A Paris court Wednesday sentenced a former Liberian rebel commander to life in jail over violence against civilians and complicity in crimes against humanity after France's first trial linked to Liberia's civil wars.
articles.title: French court sentences Liberian ex-rebel commander to life in prison

articles.author: Joanna YORK
articles.description: US intelligence officials on Monday delivered an updated report on UFO sightings to Congress, parts of which are expected to be declassified and made available online later this week. It is the latest in a series of investigations from respected American institutions bringing UFOs into the mainstream.
articles.title: 'Possibility for real scientific discovery’: US steps up investigations into UFOs

articles.author: Barbara GABEL
articles.description: On November 2, 1992, the French Parliament unanimously approved legislation criminalising sexual harassment for the first time. This law – which applies to the workplace, public spaces and even online – is constantly evolving to better identify situations and protect victims.
articles.title: 'Many legal tools are available': Fighting sexual harassment in France today

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Warring sides in the brutal two-year conflict in Ethiopia's Tigray have agreed to a truce, the African Union's mediator said Wednesday following marathon talks in South Africa.
articles.title: Warring parties in Ethiopia's Tigray conflict agree to truce

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Arab leaders convened on Wednesday in Algeria for the second day of the 31st summit of the largest annual Arab conference, seeking common ground on several divisive issues in the region. The meeting comes against the backdrop of rising inflation, food and energy shortages, drought and soaring cost of living across the Middle East and Africa.
articles.title: Leaders hold final day of Arab League summit amid cost of living crisis

articles.description: Twitter users have been circulating a video that appears to show Elon Musk, the new owner of Twitter, firing an employee in the middle of an appearance on the Joe Rogan podcast. Certain corners of Twitter, frustrated by limits on what they could tweet, have been celebrating Musk’s takeover, saying that he will “return freedom of expression” to the platform. They saw this public firing as the first step, claiming that Vijaya Gedde, the employee in the video, had been “responsible for censorship”. But Musk didn’t fire Gedde publicly: this video is a montage of footage from two different interviews.
articles.title: No, Elon Musk didn’t fire a Twitter employee live on the radio

articles.author: FRANCE 24
articles.description: Ahead of the November 8 midterms, FRANCE 24 takes you on a tour down the Mississippi River with a series of reports by Fanny Allard. The third of five episodes brings us to Missouri, which has some of the weakest gun laws and one of the highest gun violence rates in the US.
articles.title: 'Just irresponsible': Gun violence a big issue in Missouri ahead of midterms

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Temperatures in Europe have increased at more than twice the global average over the past three decades, showing the fastest rise of any continent on earth, the UN said Wednesday.
articles.title: European temperatures have risen more than twice global average, UN says

articles.author: FRANCE 24
articles.description: One week after his death aged 102, a national tribute was in honour of French painter Pierre Soulages in the Louvre on Wednesday, presided over by President Emmanuel Macron.
articles.title: France hosts national tribute ceremony for artist Pierre Soulages

articles.author: Alison SARGENT
articles.description: French journalist Laurent Richard founded Forbidden Stories in 2017 with a simple mission: to continue the work of journalists who have been assassinated or otherwise silenced. That same year, Maltese journalist Daphne Caruana Galizia was killed in a car bomb. The organisation worked to continue her investigations and identify her killers, exposing corruption at the highest levels of the Maltese government. For Richard, the ultimate goal of Forbidden Stories is twofold: to bring crucial reporting to the world and to deter crimes against journalists by showing that "it doesn't make sense to kill a reporter when there are 50 others ready to carry on their work". He joined us for Perspective as we mark the International Day to End Impunity for Crimes Against Journalists.
articles.title: Forbidden Stories founder on continuing the work of silenced journalists

articles.author: FRANCE 24
articles.description: Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelensky Wednesday hailed "a significant diplomatic result for our country and the whole world" after Russia rejoined a deal to allow Ukrainian grain exports via the Black Sea. Follow our live blog for the latest developments. All times are Paris local time (GMT+1).
articles.title: Live: Zelensky says grain deal resumption important for 'whole world'

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Veteran Israeli politician Benjamin Netanyahu appeared on the cusp of returning to power Wednesday, with initial election results showing his alliance with the extreme right taking a narrow lead.
articles.title: Netanyahu on cusp of election victory with far-right allies

articles.author: FRANCE 24
articles.description: The small village of Vysokopillya in southern Ukraine was quick to fall into Russian hands when Moscow invaded on February 24. But in September – after six months of Russian occupation – it was recaptured by Ukrainian forces, who have now set up camp there. FRANCE 24’s Gulliver Cragg reports on the soldiers’ daily lives, some 40 kilometres from the frontline.
articles.title: Short on equipment, high on morale: FRANCE 24 reports from recaptured town in Ukraine

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro once took a stab at predicting the outcome of his 2022 re-election bid: "Prison, death or victory."
articles.title: What's next for Brazil's Bolsonaro?

articles.author: Romain HOUEIX
articles.description: Less than three weeks before the tournament kicks off, the Qatar World Cup remains shrouded in controversy – largely due to the deaths of migrants constructing the stadiums under dreadful conditions. FRANCE 24 spoke to the co-author of a new book detailing their plight.
articles.title: ‘Just hell’: New book shines light on migrant deaths ahead of Qatar World Cup

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: North Korea fired at least 23 missiles into the sea on Wednesday, including one that landed less than 60 kilometres off South Korea’s coast, which the South’s President Yoon Suk-yeol described as “territorial encroachment”.
articles.title: N. Korean missile lands off S.Korean coast for first time, South responds with own launches

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Denmark’s left-leaning bloc will maintain a slim majority in parliament after all votes in a general election were counted, paving the way for another term for Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen and her Social Democratic Party.
articles.title: Danish left-wing bloc retains a majority in parliament

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: The man accused of breaking into House Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s home, beating her husband and seeking to kidnap her told police he was on a “suicide mission” and had plans to target other California and federal politicians, according to a Tuesday court filing.
articles.title: Pelosi suspect told police he was on a “suicide mission”

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: On a topsy-turvy night, Tottenham and Eintracht Frankfurt both came from behind to win their respective games and secure their places in the last 16 of the Champions League.
articles.title: Champions League: Tottenham beat Marseille, Frankfurt beat Lisbon

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: The party of Israel's veteran ex-premier Benjamin Netanyahu was set to come first in Tuesday's vote, initial projections indicated, but there was no guarantee he could form a government.
articles.title: Netanyahu poised for comeback in Israel election, initial projections show

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Denmark's left-wing bloc led by Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen appeared to take the lead in Tuesday's general election but without a majority, exit polls showed, setting the new centrist Moderate party up as likely kingmaker.
articles.title: Exit polls show no clear winning majority in Denmark election

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi said lessons must be learned as he visited the site of a bridge collapse that killed 135 people and met some of the injured in hospital on Tuesday.
articles.title: India's Modi visits bridge collapse site, calls for 'extensive inquiry'

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: French media organisations have called for the release of a reporter on assignment to cover protests in Iran for French-German TV channel Arte which reported his arrest.
articles.title: French media demand Iran release reporter covering Mahsa Amini protests

articles.author: FRANCE 24
articles.description: October 2022 is set to be the hottest month of October in France since records started in 1900, national weather agency Meteo-France said in a statement Tuesday.
articles.title: France had hottest October ever: national weather agency

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: The rapper Takeoff, a member of the Grammy-nominated hip hop trio Migos, was fatally shot at a bowling alley in Houston, Texas on Tuesday, according to entertainment outlet TMZ. He was 28 years old.
articles.title: Rapper Takeoff, member of hip hop trio Migos, shot dead at 28, says TMZ

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Iranians staged new protest actions to denounce the country’s theocratic regime in defiance of a crackdown that is now seeing those arrested put on trial and facing the death penalty.
articles.title: Despite deadly crackdowns, Iranians continue anti-regime protests

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: The aftermath of a large star’s explosive death is seen in an image released on Monday by the European Southern Observatory, showing immense filaments of brightly shining gas that was blasted into space during the supernova.
articles.title: Space observatory releases stunning image of giant star's 'ghost'

articles.author: FRANCE 24
articles.description: Hundreds of people descended on the streets of the Democratic Republic of Congo's city of Goma on Monday, chanting for weapons to fight Rwanda, as M23 rebels continued their advance on the North Kivu province. The protesters accuse its smaller neighbour of actively backing the militia, and on the weekend, the government asked the Rwandan ambassador to leave. FRANCE 24’s Aurélie Bazzara-Kibangula and Justin Kabumba report.
articles.title: Hundreds take to streets in DR Congo for anti-Rwanda protests

articles.author: FRANCE 24
articles.description: Ahead of the November 8 midterms, FRANCE 24 takes you on a tour down the Mississippi River with a series of reports by Fanny Allard. The second of five episodes brings us to La Crosse, Wisconsin, where all abortion clinics in the state have closed since the Supreme Court overturned the landmark ruling guaranteeing American women access to abortion. Since then, new female voter registration has surged in Wisconsin, and activists are hoping the right to abortion will be a key issue in the elections.
articles.title: Female voter registration for Wisconsin midterms surges after abortion ban

articles.author: FRANCE 24
articles.description: Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelensky said Tuesday that the grain shipping corridor to get food out of his country, part of an agreement Russia has suspended, needs reliable, long-term protection. Lawyers in Britain earlier took the first step towards what they said was "groundbreaking" legal action against Russia's shadowy Wagner group over allegations it committed "terrorism" in Ukraine. Follow our live blog for the latest developments. All times are Paris local time (GMT+1).
articles.title: Live: Zelensky calls for 'long-term protection' of Ukraine grain corridor

articles.author: Gwendoline DEBONO
articles.description: Israelis have been called to the polls for the fifth legislative elections in less than four years. The latest polls show that the different blocs are neck-and-neck, and one element will prove decisive: the participation of the Arab community, who make up 20 percent of Israel's population. FRANCE 24's Josh Vardey and Gwendoline Debono report from Israel.
articles.title: Arab voters could prove decisive in upcoming Israeli elections

articles.author: FRANCE 24
articles.description: Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro made an official statement after his election defeat on Tuesday evening, thanking Brazilian voters who voted for him and saying that he will continue to follow the constitution. His chief of staff says that he will begin the process of transition with President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva. Follow our live blog for the latest developments. All times are Paris time (GMT+1).
articles.title: Live: Bolsonaro says he will 'comply' with the constitution after election loss

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: South Korea’s police chief admitted "a heavy responsibility" for failing to prevent a recent crowd surge that killed more than 150 people during Halloween festivities in Seoul, saying Tuesday that officers didn’t effectively handle earlier emergency calls about the impending disaster.
articles.title: South Korea police admit response to Halloween crowd surge was inadequate

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Arab leaders meet in the Algerian capital on Tuesday for their first summit since a string of normalisation deals with Israel that have divided the region.
articles.title: Algeria hosts first Arab League summit since normalisation deals with Israel

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Neymar’s trial concluded on Monday with the company that accused him of fraud and corruption reducing the prison sentence it sought for the player’s alleged involvement in irregularities related to his transfer from Santos to Barcelona in 2013.
articles.title: Neymar trial concludes after Spain prosecutors drop charges

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: The man accused of bludgeoning US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's husband with a hammer after breaking into the couple's home threatened to take her hostage and break her kneecaps if she lied under his questioning, according to a federal criminal complaint filed on Monday.
articles.title: Pelosi suspect charged with trying to take US house speaker hostage

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Billionaire Elon Musk said on Monday in a filing that he will be the chief executive officer of Twitter, the social media company he recently acquired for $44 billion.
articles.title: Elon Musk says he will be Twitter CEO

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Russian President Vladimir Putin said Monday he hopes for "normalisation" of ties between rivals Armenia and Azerbaijan who pledged not to resort to force in their territorial dispute after tripartite talks, reasserting Moscow's role as Caucasus powerbroker.
articles.title: Armenia and Azerbaijan pledge 'not to use force' over Nagorno-Karabakh region

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Paul Pogba will miss France's World Cup defence as he needs more time to recover from knee surgery, his agent announced on Monday.
articles.title: France's Pogba to miss World Cup over knee injury

articles.author: FRANCE24
articles.description: Starlink, the satellite internet service provided by Elon Musk’s SpaceX, has become a vital tool for Ukraine’s drone operators, allowing them to relay the coordinates of Russian positions to artillery units in real time. But the future of use of Starlink by Ukrainian forces has been thrown into doubt in recent weeks after Musk suggested his company may no longer provide it for free.
articles.title: ‘Starlink is the difference’: Internet connection gives Ukraine edge in drone war

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Iranian authorities announced on Monday they will hold public trials for 1,000 people in the capital, Tehran, over the protests that have convulsed the country. The mass indictments mark the government's first major legal action aimed at quashing dissent since unrest erupted over six weeks ago.
articles.title: Iran to hold public trials for 1,000 people involved in Mahsa Amini protests

articles.author: FRANCE 24
articles.description: Truckers protested the defeat of outgoing President Jair Bolsonaro Monday by blocking national highways. Bolsonaro had yet to concede defeat Monday morning following a tight race, raising fears the far-right nationalist might contest the victory of his leftist rival Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva. Follow FRANCE 24 for live updates. All times are Paris time (GMT+2).
articles.title: Live: Bolsonaro remains silent after Brazil election defeat, supporters block highways

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Nine people were arrested Monday in connection with the collapse of a pedestrian bridge in western India that killed at least 137 people, police said.
articles.title: Indian police arrest nine in connection with deadly bridge collapse

sources.title: World News - Breaking international news and headlines | Sky News

articles.description: Elon Musk tweeted a link to an unfounded rumour about the attack on Nancy Pelosi's husband - just days after he bought the platform sparking fears it would no longer seek to limit misinformation and hate speech.

articles.description: In his first speech as Brazilian President-elect, Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva promised to unite a divided country - and stop the deforestation of the Amazon.
articles.title: World reacts to comeback of Lula, Brazil's president-elect, and his robust rainforest promises

articles.description: Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva has won the Brazilian election, narrowly beating Jair Bolsonaro, official figures show.

articles.description: At least 81 people have died after a suspension bridge collapsed in India.
articles.title: At least 81 people dead after suspension bridge collapses in India

articles.description: In the south-western corner of Lithuania, in the town of Vistytis, they know their enemy well.

articles.description: Britain has denied Russian claims that Royal Navy personnel blew up the Nord Stream gas pipelines last month, saying the story is "invented".

articles.description: A gossip column threatening to "out" actress Rebel Wilson was "likely to cause substantial offence and distress", the Australian Press Council has found.
articles.title: Gossip column 'outing' of Rebel Wilson condemned by Australian Press Council

articles.description: The commander of Iran's powerful Revolutionary Guards has warned protesters not to leave their homes to demonstrate and that Saturday will be the "last day" of taking to the streets.

articles.description: A man wanted in connection with the deaths of 39 people found in the back of an Essex lorry has appeared in court this morning.

articles.description: At least 45 people have died following a tropical storm in the Philippines, with officials fearing the death toll could continue to rise.

articles.description: The largest automaker in the US has pulled paid advertising on Twitter after Elon Musk completed his takeover of the social media company.
articles.title: Largest US automaker pulls ads from Twitter after Elon Musk's takeover

articles.description: Joe Biden has described the violent assault on US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's husband as "despicable" – as San Francisco's police chief has said it was "not a random attack".
articles.title: Biden condemns 'despicable' attack on Nancy Pelosi's husband - as police say assault was 'intentional'

articles.description: A Royal Navy ship has stopped and torched a boat caught smuggling £24m of cocaine in the Caribbean.
articles.title: Royal Navy ship torches smugglers' boat carrying £24m of cocaine in Caribbean

articles.description: An artwork has been hanging upside down - for more than 75 years.
articles.title: An easy mistake? Artwork hung upside down for 75 years

articles.description: Britain's Ministry of Defence sent serving Royal Air Force pilots to China to teach a course to their Chinese counterparts and allowed Chinese nationals to study at UK military colleges, Sky News can reveal.
articles.title: UK sent RAF pilots to teach Chinese counterparts and allowed students to attend British military colleges

articles.author: Heidi Lee
articles.description: Champagne's order comes less than a week after he said Canada would be limiting the involvement of foreign state-owned companies in the industry.
articles.title: Ottawa seeks to cut China out of Canadian critical mineral industry

articles.description: Nikolas Cruz received a sentence for killing 17 students and staff during the Feb. 14, 2018, massacre at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in suburban Fort Lauderdale.

articles.description: Pointing in particular to the attack on House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's husband, the president warned false claims of election fraud are fueling a rise in political violence.
articles.title: Biden warns democracy is at stake in U.S. midterms, urges voters to reject violence

articles.description: Residents in central Japan were warned to shelter indoors, according to the Japanese government's broadcast warning system. The ballistic missile landed in the Pacific Ocean.
articles.title: North Korea launches ballistic missile over Japan, prompting warnings to seek shelter

articles.description: One looming crisis the ministers had expected to address at the meeting was averted Wednesday when Russia agreed to resume a wartime agreement that allowed Ukrainian grain.
articles.title: G7 foreign ministers to discuss Ukraine war, China’s threat to Taiwan

articles.author: Emily Mertz
articles.description: A judge ruled Wednesday that the Oregon man accused of exploiting, abducting and sexually abusing a 13-year-old girl from Edmonton will remain behind bars until his trial.
articles.title: No pre-trial release for Noah Madrano, man charged in 13-year-old Edmonton girl’s abduction, abuse

articles.description: Trudeau says Canada is weighing how to respond to Haiti's request for military intervention, amid widespread violence and a deadly cholera outbreak.
articles.title: Trudeau meet with ministers on Haiti, says ‘we have to intervene’ somehow

articles.description: Some professionals think that there are downsides to staying on the platform because Elon Musk has emboldened Twitter users running bots or spreading harm.
articles.title: Musk’s Twitter takeover: Some Canadian professionals thinking of quitting platform. Why?

articles.description: The North Koreans have shown interest in sending construction workers to help rebuild Russian-occupied territories in the country's east.
articles.title: North Korea is secretly supplying Russia with artillery, White House says

articles.description: The war in Ukraine has killed tens of thousands and triggered the biggest confrontation with the West since the 1962 Cuban Missile Crisis.

articles.description: David DePape told police he was on a ``suicide mission'' and had plans to target other California and federal politicians, according to a Tuesday court filing.

articles.description: The shooter, identified only as ``Patrick C'' in line with Mexican law enforcement policy, then entered his home and set fire to it before running back out.
articles.title: Canadian in custody after allegedly killing Mexican police officer in shooting

articles.description: Polls by three major Israeli TV stations indicated that the former prime minister and his allies would capture the 61-seat majority in parliament required to form a new government.
articles.title: Israel election: Netanyahu on track to regain power, exit polls suggest

articles.description: It took Bolsonaro more than 44 hours to make his first public remarks since his narrow election loss to leftist Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, which has led to protests across Brazil.
articles.title: Brazil’s Bolsonaro avoids conceding election defeat, but allows transition to begin

articles.description: Foxconn, one of Apple's largest suppliers, is dealing with a COVID-19 crisis at its biggest iPhone assembly factory in Zhengzhou, China.

articles.author: Rachel Gilmore
articles.description: Complaints of foreign interference in Canada's elections also slightly increased in 2021, the committee heard on Tuesday — but officials noted the complaints are allegations.
articles.title: CSIS is ‘increasingly concerned’ about China’s interference in Canada

articles.description: The United States is concerned about threats from Iran against Saudi Arabia and will not hesitate to respond if necessary, a White House spokesperson said on Tuesday.
articles.title: U.S. concerned over threat of Iranian attack in Saudi Arabia, vows response

articles.author: Kathryn Mannie
articles.description: Police assembled hundreds of pairs of crumpled tennis shoes, loafers and Chuck Taylors in the aftermath of South Korea's deadliest crowd surge in history.
articles.title: Hundreds of lost shoes await owners after deadly crowd crush in South Korea

articles.description: Pfizer's maternal vaccine is the same recipe it tested successfully in older adults and it plans to seek Food and Drug Administration approval for those vaccinations by year's end.
articles.title: Vaccinating pregnant women with new RSV vaccine helped protect newborns: Pfizer

articles.description: Russia, which launched its "special military operation" in Ukraine in February, has announced it has completed a mobilization drive ordered in September.
articles.title: Russia starts larger evacuation of occupied southern Ukraine amid counteroffensive

articles.description: The 50 countries urged China to clarify ``the fate and whereabouts of missing family members'' and arrange safe contacts and reunions.
articles.title: Canada among 50 countries urging China to release detained Uyghurs

articles.description: Since the takeover Musk has moved quickly to put his stamp on Twitter, which he had ridiculed for months for being slow to introduce product changes or take down spam accounts.
articles.title: ‘Chief Twit’: Elon Musk says he will now be Twitter CEO

articles.description: Justice Vsevolod Kniaziev said the system is doing its best to adapt in an attempt to fill institutional gaps and hold offenders accountable for war crimes.
articles.title: Ukraine holding war criminals to account despite judicial system woes: chief justice

articles.author: Emily Mertz
articles.description: The U.S. department of justice alleges Noah Madrano, 41, kidnapped an Edmonton girl from outside her school and eventually drove her back to the U.S. in the trunk of his vehicle.
articles.title: Oregon man facing federal charges in alleged abduction, abuse of 13-year-old Edmonton girl

articles.description: A team tasked with assessing the crisis in Haiti is now briefing senior officials as the Canadian government weighs a potential military mission to assist the beleaguered nation.
articles.title: Canadian officials return from Haiti as Ottawa weighs military response to crisis

articles.description: Some truckers at roadblocks called for a military coup to prevent Lula becoming president, as protests spread across the country and threatened to cause economic chaos.
articles.title: Brazilian truckers block roads in protest of Bolsonaro’s election defeat to Lula

articles.author: Aaron D’Andrea
articles.description: National Defence Minister Anita Anand is suggesting Canada can become a leader in providing Ukraine with armoured vehicles, but is that actually possible?
articles.title: Canada can be ‘leader’ in providing Ukraine with armoured vehicles: Anand

articles.author: Kristen Robinson
articles.description: The suspect in the Pelosi home break-in has roots in Powell River, B.C. – where some in the Sunshine Coast community of just under 14,000 remember David DePape as an ordinary teen.
articles.title: ‘Just your average student’: Former school counsellor remembers Pelosi break-in suspect David DePape

articles.author: Heidi Lee
articles.description: The motion declares the House of Commons' support for the removal of Iran from the UN Commission on the Status of Women has been adopted by unanimous consent.
articles.title: House of Commons backs call to remove Iran from UN’s commission on status of women

articles.description: David DePape is charged with influencing, impeding, or retaliating against a federal official by threatening or injuring a family member, and attempted kidnapping of an official.
articles.title: Suspect in Pelosi husband attack faces 2 charges, including attempted kidnapping

sources.title: The Seattle Times World – The Seattle Times

articles.author: MARCOS ALEMAN
articles.description: El Salvador’s government has taken its efforts against the country’s powerful street gangs to another level by sending inmates into cemeteries to destroy the tombs of gang members at a time of year when families typically visit their loved ones’ graves.
articles.title: El Salvador fights gangs by destroying members’ tombstones

articles.author: KIM TONG-HYUNG and MARI YAMAGUCHI

sources.title: Latest World News Headlines | Daily Telegraph

articles.description:
US President Joe Biden has delivered a speech near the US Capitol a week out from the midterm elections.

“We are facing a defining moment – an inflection point – we must with one overwhelming, unified voice speak as a country and say there is no place, no place for voter intimidation or political violence in America,” Mr Biden said. 

“Whether it’s directed at Democrats or Republicans. 

“No place period. No place ever.”
articles.title: President Biden says political violence has ‘no place’ in America

articles.description:
The White House has announced President Joe Biden will make an unscheduled speech near the US Capitol a week out from the midterm elections. 

President Biden’s speech is expected to be about preserving democracy with a strong focus on the January 6 Capitol riot and the hope that it will encourage Americans to go out and vote for Democrats next week.
articles.title: Biden to deliver speech on democracy near US Capitol

articles.description:
US President Joe Biden has appealed to Americans to vote as the midterm elections looms closer with only one week to go. 

President Biden was at the US Capitol today to give a speech on democracy as he encouraged Americans to vote. 

“Recent polls have shown that overwhelming majority of Americans believe our democracy is at risk, that democracy is under threat,” he said. 

“They too see that democracy is on the ballot this year, and they’re deeply concerned about it. 

“Today, I appeal to all Americans, regardless of party, to meet this moment of national and generational importance. 

“We must vote knowing what’s at stake and not just the policy of the moment.”
articles.title: ‘Democracy is on the ballot this year’: Biden appeals to voters ahead of the US midterms

articles.description:
Russia has decided to rejoin the Black Sea grain deal as Moscow ramps up their attacks on Ukraine's energy facilities. 

Under the agreement, Ukraine had been able to restart grain and fertiliser exports which had stalled due to the ongoing war with Russia.

Russia had previously suspended its participation in the deal after a drone attack on its warships.
articles.title: Russian rejoins grain export deal with Ukraine

articles.description: Wonder Land: Russia, China and Iran are now in an alliance whose explicit goal is to replace the U.S. and its liberal values. Ukraine is their central, active battlefield. Images: Reuters/AFP/AP/Getty Images Composite: Mark Kelly
articles.title: WSJ Opinion: Will U.S. Turn its Back on Putin’s Cold War in Ukraine?

articles.description: President Biden on Wednesday urged Americans to reject political violence and voter intimidation, and warned against candidates who haven’t committed to accepting the midterm results. Photo: Michael A. McCoy/Getty Images
articles.title: Watch: Biden Condemns Political Violence, Intimidation

articles.description:
Perth USAsia Centre’s Hayley Channer says we must “demonstrate the value” of our infrastructure offerings to developing nations in order to “compete with China” amid Beijing's growing influence in the Indo-Pacific region. 

“China is able to build almost anything, anywhere, for anyone,” Ms Channer told Sky News Australia.

“The US has a lot of restrictions in terms of what it will actually build, and who it will build it for.

“We need to start building things more quickly.”
articles.title: Western infrastructure must ‘compete with China’

articles.description: A TikTok star hatched a plot to “silence” her mother’s secret lover after he tried to blackmail her with a sex tape, a court has heard.
articles.title: TikTok star charged with murder of mum’s ex

articles.description: Former chess world champion Anatoly Karpov has been found badly injured outside Russia’s parliament after calling for an end to Vladimir Putin’s invasion of Ukraine.
articles.title: ‘Unfortunate accident’ as Putin criticised

articles.description: A missile launched by North Korea – the 30th this year alone – has sparked panicked evacuation warnings in nearby Japan, as the rogue nation’s recent barrage leaves the entire region on edge.
articles.title: ‘Evacuate’: Chaos as North Korea fires missile

articles.description:
Former UK prime minister Boris Johnson has given his first interview since standing down. 

Mr Johnson confirmed he will be travelling to Egypt for the COP27 climate summit next week.
articles.title: Boris Johnson to attend COP27 in Egypt

The US prepares to deploy nuclear-capable B52 Bombers to be rotated through an airbase south of Darwin.
articles.title: China warns of arms race in the Top End

articles.description: Whether the brutal attack on Paul Pelosi or the shooting of Steve Scalise in 2017, one of the root causes of escalating attacks on lawmakers today is the inflammatory rhetoric from politicians and media personalities on both the left and right sides of the aisle. Images: AFP/Getty Images Composite: Mark Kelly
articles.title: WSJ Opinion: The Fine Line Between Heated Rhetoric and Political Violence

articles.description:
South Korean officials have accepted responsibility for the deadly Halloween stampede which occurred in the Itaewon district of Seoul. 

The death toll from the crowd surge rose on Tuesday to 156, with another 152 people injured during the incident on Saturday night. 

National Police Commissioner General Yoon Hee-keun has admitted their emergency response to the incident was “inadequate”. 

It's understood multiple calls for help were made to emergency services before the event turned fatal.

An investigation has been launched into the incident and the response of police.
articles.title: South Korean officials admit responsibility for deadly stampede

articles.description: Survivors and family members of those killed in the 2018 shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School remembered loved ones and addressed defendant Nikolas Cruz, at his sentencing hearing in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., Tuesday. Photo: Amy Beth Bennett/Press Pool
articles.title: Survivors, Family Speak to Parkland School Shooter at Sentencing Hearing

articles.description: Former British health secretary Matt Hancock has signed up as a contestant on the reality TV show, ‘I am a Celebrity…Get Me Out Of Here!’ - sparking outrage among UK Conservative Party members.
articles.title: UK Conservative Party members outraged by former MP signing up to a reality TV show

articles.description:
India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi has called for a “detailed inquiry” into a bridge collapse which killed 135 people on Sunday. 

Mr Modi visited the site of the incident and a hospital to meet people who were injured.

It's understood hundreds of people were on the structure when it gave way. 

Divers are currently searching for more victims.

Nine people have been arrested on charges including culpable homicide not amounting to murder.
articles.title: India’s PM visits site of bridge collapse

articles.description:
Elon Musk has teased fans on Twitter by weighing in on whether former president Donald Trump will be allowed to return to the social media platform after being kicked off in January 2021.

“If I had a dollar for every time someone asked me if Trump was coming back on this platform, Twitter would be minting money,” Elon Musk tweeted.

Fans of the 45th president begged the new owner to allow him back on the platform, with one user calling Donald Trump’s permanent suspension “the most outrageous act of censorship in modern America”.
articles.title: Elon Musk comments on Donald Trump returning to Twitter

articles.description:
Prince Harry was slammed by a royal expert as an "emotionally needy" man who has been "completely and utterly taken over" by his wife Meghan Markle.

Tina Brown, author of 'The Palace Papers: Inside the House of Windsor - the Truth and the Turmoil', told The Telegraph ahead of the release of her new book earlier this year that the Duke of Sussex's "whole personality has changed".

"He’s so emotionally needy that he’s been completely and utterly taken over by Meghan and his whole personality has changed. It’s a really sad thing to a great many people," she told the publication.

"Meghan seems to answer some huge need in Harry and it seems like they are in a powerful co-dependency. And I do question how it will end."
articles.title: ‘Emotionally needy’ Prince Harry ‘completely and utterly taken over’ by Meghan

articles.description:
China has warned a build-up of defence assets in the Northern Territory could start an arms race in the region. 

This comes amid reports the US Air Force could deploy nuclear-capable bombers to the Northern Territory.

“The relevant US behaviours have increased regional tensions, seriously undermined regional peace and stability and may trigger an arms race in the region,” Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Zhao Lijian said. 

“China urges the parties concerned to abandon the outdated cold war and … narrow-minded geopolitical thinking.”
articles.title: China warns of arms race amid reports US B-52 bombers will be deployed to NT

articles.description: San Francisco District Attorney Brooke Jenkins on Monday announced state crime charges including attempted murder against David DePape, the man accused of attacking House Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s husband. Photo: Justin Sullivan/Getty Images
articles.title: San Francisco DA Announces Charges Against Alleged Paul Pelosi Attacker

articles.description:
US President Joe Biden has said to big energy companies they are making “windfall profits” as a result of Russia’s war with Ukraine, and the United States “expects something of that back,” Sky News Business Editor Ross Greenwood says. 

Mr Biden stated during a recent press conference that the current record profits of oil companies “are not because they are doing something new or innovative”.

“Their profits are a windfall of war,” he said.
articles.title: President Biden says profits of oil companies are a ‘windfall of war’

articles.description:
Former White House chief of staff Mick Mulvaney says the Democrats have “kept Biden mostly at home” over the last couple of days during the US midterm elections campaign. 

“We understand that Joe Biden may be out in Pennsylvania, it’s very close to his home state, that one makes some sense, but he won’t be going across the country like (former) president Obama will,” Mr Mulvaney told Sky News Australia. 

“Obama’s probably the most popular Democrat right now nationwide and if I were the Democrats, I’d be doing the exact same thing.”
articles.title: Democrats have kept Biden ‘mostly at home’ over the last couple of days

articles.description:
Around 3 million Texans have already cast their vote in next week's midterm elections. 

The southern state hosts several interesting contests - including for the Governorship - as Democrat and failed presidential candidate Beto O'Rourke tries to oust Republican Greg Abbott. 

With the midterm elections approaching quickly, more and more Americans are talking about the issue of cost of living. 

Sky News spoke to Texans to discuss their key election issues as Americans gear up to head to the polls for the midterms, with some pointing to the cost of living crisis, gun laws, and abortion rights.
articles.title: The economy is ‘swirling’: Texans discuss their key election issues before the midterms

articles.description:
Former White House chief of staff Mick Mulvaney says traditionally, the party in power does “really poorly” in their first midterm elections. 

“This a repetition that goes back 100 years in my country,” Mr Mulvaney told Sky News Australia. 

He said the reason the Republicans stand to do well in the midterms is because the Democrats continue to talk about abortion when undecided voters are more focussed on the economy and the cost of living crisis.
articles.title: The party in power tends to do ‘really poorly’ in their first US midterm elections

articles.description: A young Sydney woman has been identified as the Australian victim of the Halloween crowd surge that killed at least 154 people in South Korea.
articles.title: Seoul stampede: Sydney woman Grace Rached identified as Australian victim

articles.description:
An extradition trial date has been set for the woman arrested over the deaths of two children whose bodies were found in suitcases in Auckland, New Zealand.

Sky News New Zealand Chief Bureau Chief Jessica Maggio says the trial is set to take place on November 14  in South Korea, where the woman was arrested.

“She’s suspected of being involved in the deaths of two children whose bodies were found in suitcases in Auckland after being acquired at a storage facility auction," she said.

“Authorities have confirmed they believe the victims are a boy and a girl between the ages of five and 10.”
articles.title: Extradition trial date set for woman arrested over NZ suitcase murders

articles.description:
DW: Denmark: No clear winner, ex-PM to play key role — exit poll 
Former Prime Minister Lars Lokke Rasmussen is set to play a pivotal role after an inconclusive election result, exit polls have revealed. 
Neither the ruling left nor the right-wing opposition are set to win a majority. 
Former Danish Prime Minister Lars Lokke Rasmussen looked set to become the Scandinavian country's proverbial kingmaker after an inconclusive election result, according to exit polls on Tuesday, with neither the ruling left nor right-wing opposition set to secure enough seats.   
Read more ....   
WNU Editor: It looks like Denmark's ruling centre-left coalition have lost their majority. Final results will be known in the next few days. 
Exit Polls Show No Clear Winner In Denmark Election   
Exit poll points to no clear winner in Danish election -- AP  
Exit polls show no clear winning majority in Denmark election -- France 24  
Denmark election: Social Democrats lead but no majority, exit poll suggests -- The Guardian  
Danish vote paves way for centrist government: exit poll -- Politico
articles.title: Exit Polls Show No Clear Winner In Denmark Election

articles.description:
DW: Israel election: Exit polls put Netanyahu's party ahead 
Exit polls show ex-premier Benjamin Netanyahu's party securing the most seats in parliament. 
It's Israel's fifth national election since 2019.  Former Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and his right-wing allies secured an early lead in Israel's latest national election, according to exit polls released on Tuesday night after voting closed. 
Exit polls published by Israeli broadcasters showed former Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's Likud party and allied parties close to securing a majority in the 120-seat Knesset.   
Read more .... 
WNU Editor: Netanyahu is no friend of the Biden White House. He has also vowed to undo the US brokered maritime deal with Lebanon. It looks like there is going to be a lot of friction between the U.S. and Israel.

Israeli Exit Polls Put Netanyahu's Party On Course To Form The Next Government

Netanyahu poised for comeback in Israel election, initial projections show -- France 24

articles.description:
Daily Mail: Brazilian President Bolsonaro avoids saying he concedes defeat in first speech since losing election to leftist Lula - but his chief of staff says transition to new government will begin 
* In a national address that lasted just a few minutes, Bolsonaro thanked Brazilians 
* He didn't mention election results but reiterated he would follow the constitution 
* He said protests since then were the fruit of 'indignation and a sense of injustice' 
Brazil's far-right President Jair Bolsonaro failed to concede defeat to leftist Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva in his first public remarks since losing Sunday's election. 
In a national address on Tuesday that lasted just a few minutes, Bolsonaro thanked Brazilians who voted for him. 
He didn't mention election results, but reiterated that he would follow the country's constitution, which stipulates a transition of power on January 1.   
Read more ....   
WNU Editor: The important thing is that the transition to a new government is beginning. 
Brazilian President Bolsonaro Declines To Concede The Election To Lula da Silva But Orders The Transition To Begin

Brazil's Jair Bolsonaro avoids conceding election to Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva but transition set to begin -- ABC News Australia

articles.description:
The Iranian military displays missles at Tehran’s Baharestan square to commemorate the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war during “sacred defense week” September 25, 2003. (Morteza Nikoubazl/Reuters)   
FOX News: US, Saudi Arabia on high alert over intel of impending Iranian attack: report 
Planned strikes are believed to be targeting Saudi Arabia and Iraq 
The United States and Saudi Arabia are on high alert after Saudi intelligence shared with the U.S. indicated that Iran is expected to carry out an attack on targets in Saudi Arabia, the Wall Street Journal reported. 
Officials from both countries reportedly told the Journal about the concern over coming attacks. Saudi officials said that in addition to Saudi Arabia, Iran is also looking to strike Erbil, Iraq, where U.S. troops are located. 
The planned attacks are said to be intended as a distraction from protests taking place in Iran against the Islamic nation's leadership. 
Read more ... 
WNU Editor: I follow Iran very closely. I have seen no uptick in military positioning or movement. I would be shocked if Iran does launch strikes against Saudi Arabia. 
All that I can say is let us pray that such a conflict does not happen. A major war in the Middle East will mean +$200 for a barrel of oil coupled with widespread shortages and rationing. A collapse in supply chains and the global economy. A severe recession, or more likely a severe depression with massive unemployment and social unrest. 
Saudi Arabia And U.S. On High Alert After Intelligence Warning Of Imminent Iranian Attack   
U.S. concerned about Iranian threats to Saudi Arabia -- Reuters  
Pentagon ‘Concerned’ About Indications of Imminent Attack by Iran -- US News and World Report  
US officials warned of ‘imminent’ Iranian effort to strike Saudi Arabia, report says -- The Independent  
US on alert over ‘imminent’ Iran attack on Saudi Arabia, Iraq: report -- NYPost 
Saudi Arabia, U.S., Raise Military Alert Levels over Fears of Iranian Attack -- National Review
articles.title: Saudi Arabia And U.S. On High Alert After Intelligence Warning of Imminent Iranian Attack

articles.description:
WNU Editor: A lot of talk in alternative media that US military planes turned off their transponders early Monday morning (link here). 
I do not know if these reports are true. Main stream media is not reporting this story. Neither any of the military blogs that I follow. 
My gut tells me that if it did happen it was a test/exercise. 
Shutting down military transponders is what will happen if war breaks out between the U.S. and Russia. In this case it looks like someone wanted to test the reaction time.
articles.title: Did All U.S. Military Planes Turn-Off Their Transponders Early Monday Morning?

articles.description:
The Intercept: Truth Cops  
Leaked Documents Outline DHS’s Plans to Police Disinformation 
The Department of Homeland Security is quietly broadening its efforts to curb speech it considers dangerous, an investigation by The Intercept has found. 
Years of internal DHS memos, emails, and documents — obtained via leaks and an ongoing lawsuit, as well as public documents — illustrate an expansive effort by the agency to influence tech platforms. 
The work, much of which remains unknown to the American public, came into clearer view earlier this year when DHS announced a new “Disinformation Governance Board”: a panel designed to police misinformation (false information spread unintentionally), disinformation (false information spread intentionally), and malinformation (factual information shared, typically out of context, with harmful intent) that allegedly threatens U.S. interests. 
While the board was widely ridiculed, immediately scaled back, and then shut down within a few months, other initiatives are underway as DHS pivots to monitoring social media now that its original mandate — the war on terror — has been wound down.   
Read more ....   
WNU Editor: Sighhh .... another indication on how powerful the National Security establishment has become in the US..
articles.title: Leaked Documents Outline US Homeland Security's Plan To Work With Big Tech To Censor Social Media

In this Sept. 23, 2022, file photo, U.S. Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken (left) meets with Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi on the margins of the 77th Session of the United Nations General Assembly High Level Week, in New York City. Credit: U.S. State Department photo   
The Diplomat: Blinken, Wang Have First China-US Talks Since 20th Party Congress 
Chinese foreign minister stressed to his U.S. counterpart that Washington should not expect Beijing to change course. 
Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi and U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken talked on the phone on Monday. It was their first conversation — and the first high-level China-U.S. exchange — since the 20th National Congress of the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) concluded on October 22. 
At the party meeting, Wang was elevated to the party’s Politburo. That indicates he is to replace outgoing Yang Jiechi as China’s top diplomat – formally, the director of the Office of the Central Commission for Foreign Affairs, the CCP’s foreign policy body. Wang will move out of his foreign minister post along with the promotion. 
Read more ....   
WNU Editor: This meeting did not go well. There is no common ground right now between the two sides.

* Preliminary data on Monday from Europe’s statistics office showed headline inflation came in at an annual 10.7% this month. 
* This represents the highest ever monthly reading since the euro zone’s formation. The 19-member bloc has faced higher prices, particularly on energy and food, for the past 12 months.
* But the increases have been accentuated by Russia’s invasion of Ukraine in late February. 
Euro zone inflation rose above the 10% level in the month of October, highlighting the severity of the cost-of-living crisis in the region and adding more pressure on the European Central Bank. 
Preliminary data on Monday from Europe’s statistics office showed headline inflation came in at an annual 10.7% this month.…

Ukrainian forces have been making gains across Russian-occupied areas, with fighting intensifying in the country's east and in the southern city of Kherson.

   DW: Norway raises army alert level in response to Ukraine war 
The Norwegian armed forces will do less training and more active operations, the country's prime minister said. Oslo is concerned about sabotage to its energy infrastructure. 
Norway's Prime Minister Jonas Gahr Stoere said on Monday that his country's military would be put on a raised level of alert as part of increased security measures in response to the war in Ukraine. 
"This is the most severe security situation in several decades," Stoere told a press conference  "
There are no indications that Russia is expanding its warfare to other countries, but the increased tensions make us more exposed to threats, intelligence operations and influence campaigns." 
The increased alert level would be valid from Tuesday.   
Read more ....   
WNU Editor: I am surprised that it has taken Norway this long to raise its alert level. Everyone else in Europe is on high alert.

President Xi Jinping's successful consolidation of power rattled markets. Tingshu Wang/Reuters    
Insider: Chinese leader Xi Jinping's power grab fueled a $6 trillion stock selloff and the yuan's decline. These 4 charts capture the market meltdown 
* China's President Xi Jinping has tightened his grip on power — and that has rocked markets. 
* Investors dumped Chinese stocks in a $6 trillion blowout as Xi shut reformers out of decision making. 
* These 4 charts show how deep the meltdown in China-linked assets went last week. 
China's leader Xi Jinping has tightened his grip on power, shutting out reformers to effectively take sole charge of the world's second-largest economy — and that has rocked markets. 
President Xi unveiled a new decision-making team stacked with like-minded political allies and publicly disrespected his business-friendly predecessor at the Communist Party congress last week. 
Spooked investors dumped Chinese stocks in a $6 trillion blowout Monday, according to Bloomberg data. Meanwhile, the tightly-managed onshore yuan continued to lose ground to the dollar, having already dropped sharply this year.

Reuters: EU examines classifying Iran Revolutionary Guards as terrorists - Germany 
BERLIN (Reuters) - Germany and the European Union are examining whether to classify Iran's Revolutionary Guards as a terrorist organisation, Foreign Minister Annalena Baerbock said on Sunday. 
"I made it clear last week that we will launch another package of sanctions, that we will examine how we can also list the Revolutionary Guards as a terrorist organisation," Baerbock said in a interview with ARD broadcaster on Sunday. 
Her comments come after the head of the Revolutionary Guards warned protesters that Saturday would be their last day of taking to the streets, in a sign that security forces may intensify their already fierce crackdown on widespread unrest.

articles.description:
VICE: Facebook’s Monopoly Is Imploding Before Our Eyes 
Competition, miscalculations, and regulatory scrutiny have all but killed the advertising giant's dreams of diversifying its business and rolling up the digital world into its platform. 
For years, the definition of success for many tech employees has been getting a job at a FAANG company (Facebook, Amazon, Apple, Netflix, Google). 
Amazon, Apple, Microsoft, Facebook, and Google, meanwhile, are often the five major companies people think of when they think of "big tech." 
But there is evidence that Facebook—once a dominant monopoly rightly blamed for all sorts of societal ills—is on the precipice of dropping out of this group through years of sheer mismanagement, a failure to innovate, setting money on fire in pursuit of a metaverse that seemingly no one wants, a vulnerable business model that Apple is squarely taking aim at, and upstart competitors like TikTok that the company seemingly has no answer for. What seemed impossible just a year or two ago—that Facebook will become just another tech company, more or less—now seems like a very real possibility.   
Read more ....   
WNU Editor: It has been quite a sight to see how quickly this social media platform has lost its influence and reach in the past year. And much of what has happened has been self-inflicted. 
And while I do believe Facebook will be with us for the foreseeable future. Alternative media platforms are now online, and they are providing an environment that does not have the censorship and privacy issues that Facebook has.
articles.title: Is Facebook's Monopoly On Social Media About To End?

Hundreds of thousands of tonnes of wheat booked for delivery to Africa and the Middle East are at risk following Russia's withdrawal, while Ukrainian corn exports to Europe will get knocked lower, two Singapore-based traders said.

Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov says there are ‘similarities’ to the Cuban crisis, mainly because Russia is now threatened by Western weapons in Ukraine. 
Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov said he hopes US President Joe Biden has the wisdom to deal with a global confrontation similar to the 1962 Cuban missile crisis, referencing the war on Ukraine. 
Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has triggered the biggest hostilities between Moscow and the West since the Cuban crisis, when the Soviet Union and United States came close to a nuclear war.

WNU Editor: I remember my father telling me that during the Cuban missile crisis he was certain that there would be a nuclear war between the USSR and the United States. 
We are not there yet. But the trend lines are very worrisome on where this current conflict is heading.

Daily Mail: Liz Truss's Putin radiation terror: Ex-PM spent final days in No10 'obsessing' with wind charts and weather forecasts as her fears grew that fallout would hit UK if Putin uses nukes in Ukraine, new look inside her doomed tenure reveals 
* Truss was told Putin might explode a weapon in the air above the Black Sea

* Ms Truss became fixated with the weather after hearing about possibility 
When Liz Truss was told, during the dying days of her mayfly Premiership, that the security services were picking up intelligence that Vladimir Putin might use a tactical nuclear weapon in Ukraine it sent a chill down her spine. 
The Prime Minister was still adjusting to getting used to a new mobile phone number, for the first time in over a decade, as a result of a hack suspected to have been backed or orchestrated by the Kremlin, potentially giving Putin access to information about Western support for President Volodymyr Zelensky's regime. 
 In particular, Ms Truss was told that Putin might explode a weapon in the air above the Black Sea, which would show the West what he was capable of without triggering a full-scale nuclear war.   
Read more ....

Jerusalem Post: Israel must get rid of its nuclear weapons, UNGA majority decides 
Israel never admitted to possess nuclear weapons, but nevertheless, the UNGA resolution was aimed at Israel, not Iran.
Israel must dispose of all its nuclear weapons and place its nuclear sites under the International Atomic Energy Agency’s purview, the United Nations General Assembly’s First Committee stated in an initial 152-5 vote. 
The five nations that opposed Friday’s resolution on the “risk of nuclear proliferation in the Middle East” were: Canada, Israel, Micronesia, Palau and the United States. Another 24 countries abstained, including European Union members.

DNYUZ/Newsweek: Putin Should Be Overthrown, Majority of Americans Say: Poll 
A majority of American voters believe seeking to remove Russian President Vladimir Putin from power is a “reasonable objective,” according to a new survey conducted exclusively for Newsweek. 
On February 24 Putin ordered his army into Ukraine, triggering one of the biggest wars in Europe since the end of World War II. 
After the Russians initially made significant gains, Ukraine has recaptured some territory over the past couple of months, particularly around the northern city of Kharkiv and Kherson in the south. 
According to the Redfield and Wilton poll, conducted for Newsweek, 60 percent of U.S. voters think seeking to “remove Vladimir Putin from power would be a reasonable objective.”   
Read more ....

articles.description:
In this photo released by the Taiwan Ministry of National Defense, Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-wen watches soldiers operate equipment during a visit to a naval station on Penghu, an archipelago of several dozen islands off Taiwan's western coast on Tuesday, Aug. 30, 2022. (Taiwan Ministry of National Defense via AP)   
StraitArrowNews: Taiwan can’t fend off China without US weapons 
Since the start of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, the United States sent hundreds of millions of dollars’ worth of weaponry to the Ukrainians. Things like Javelin anti-tank missiles and HIMARS rockets. Now, as China seems poised to launch an invasion of Taiwan, some are concerned that the U.S. might not have enough weapons to help the self-governing island defend itself. 
Defending Taiwan is a vastly different undertaking from U.S. efforts with Ukraine. Unlike in Ukraine, where Russia could assemble troops along the border before invading, the Chinese would have to cross 100 miles of open ocean to launch an assault. There hasn’t been an amphibious assault on such a scale since the Korean War. 
Preventing the Chinese from establishing a beachhead would be critical to defending the island. If the Chinese succeeded in establishing a footing and is able to transport troops and weapons to the island, the battle is probably over.   
Read more ....   
WNU Editor: Fortunately for Taiwan the Chinese military have a 100 mile ocean that they must cross to launch an assault. But the Chinese will succeed if the firepower is not there to stop them. Bottom line. The Taiwanese need weapons if they have any hope to persevere.

The same can be said about the Russia - Ukraine war. If Ukraine was not receiving US military aid, the military would have collapsed a long time ago, and the Zelensky government would have been forced to agree to peace terms dictated by Moscow.
articles.title: Taiwan Needs US Weapons
